close_symbols: struct lfs_config (fields: cache_size, lookahead_size, read_buffer, prog_buffer, lookahead_buffer, ... )
typedef/struct lfs_t (fields: cfg, rcache, pcache, lookahead)
explanation:
To determine whether any string.h call (memset/memcpy/etc.) in lfs_init can access beyond object bounds you must inspect where and how buffers are zeroed/copied and how big those buffers actually are. The following symbols are required:

- lfs_cache_zero
  - Reason: This is the function called from lfs_init that is very likely to use string.h functions (e.g. memset/memcpy). You must see its prototype and implementation to know which string.h function(s) are used and what size arguments are passed.

- lfs_cache_zero implementation/source
  - Reason: The actual code is needed to verify the exact size argument passed to memset/memcpy and whether that size is derived from cfg->cache_size or other fields; only the implementation can confirm whether an out-of-bounds write/read is possible.

- struct lfs_cache (the type of lfs->rcache, lfs->pcache, lfs->lookahead)
  - Reason: You need the definition of the cache object (e.g. members: buffer pointer, any stored size) to determine which object the string.h function operates on and whether there are accompanying size fields used to bound the operation.

- struct lfs_config (at least fields cache_size, lookahead_size, read_buffer, prog_buffer, lookahead_buffer)
  - Reason: lfs_init uses cfg->cache_size and cfg->lookahead_size when allocating/assigning buffers. To check for out-of-bounds access you must know what sizes are passed to lfs_malloc and whether user-supplied buffers (read_buffer/prog_buffer/lookahead_buffer) are documented/assumed to be at least these sizes.

- typedef/struct lfs_t (fields cfg, rcache, pcache, lookahead)
  - Reason: The layout ties the config and the cache objects together; you must confirm that lfs_cache_zero receives the same cache instance whose buffer was allocated/assigned earlier in lfs_init.

- lfs_malloc (prototype/semantics)
  - Reason: lfs_init calls lfs_malloc(lfs->cfg->cache_size) and lfs_malloc(lfs->cfg->lookahead_size). To ensure no out-of-bounds access you need to know that lfs_malloc returns a pointer to at least the requested size or NULL; if lfs_malloc can return smaller blocks or has different semantics, that affects safety.

Notes:
- The critical verification is: any memset/memcpy/etc. in lfs_cache_zero (or other functions called here) must use a size that is <= the actual allocated or provided buffer size. Thus you must inspect lfs_cache_zero implementation together with struct definitions and allocation sites (lfs_malloc and the cfg->*_buffer user-supplied pointers).
- Other symbols in the static call graph (lfs_min, lfs_npw2, lfs_deinit, lfs_malloc callers) are not directly needed to check string.h bounds usage inside lfs_init, except that lfs_deinit/lfs_free may affect lifecycle but not the immediate memset/memcpy size checks.
